column1: The name "Cotonou" means "by the river of death" in the Fon language. At the beginning of the 19th century
column2: Cotonou (then spelled "Kutonou") was a small fishing village
column3: and is thought to have been formally founded by King Ghezo of Dahomey in 1830. It grew as a centre for the slave trade
column4: and later palm oil and cotton. In 1851 the French Second Republic made a treaty with King Ghezo that allowed them to establish a trading post at Cotonou. During the reign of King Glele (1858–89)
column5: the territory was ceded to the Second French Empire by a treaty signed in 1878. In 1883
column6: the French Navy occupied the city to prevent British conquest of the area. After Glele's death in 1889
column7: King Béhanzin unsuccessfully tried to challenge the treaty. The town grew rapidly following the building of the harbour in 1908.
